For each intended use, a list of the data, including attestations and attributes, 
that the relying party intends to request, a user-friendly name and a technical 
name, the attestation type and any other syntaxes that the data is grouped under, 
in a machine-readable format for automated processing.

requirements.requirement: Provide privacy policy URL for each intended use
requirements.explanation:
In Member States that use wallet-relying party registration certificates, relying 
parties must provide a URL to the privacy policy applicable to each intended use 
of wallet data. This URL is included in the registration certificate and enables 
users to verify how their data will be processed before sharing.
requirements.legalText:
Where a Member State authorised the issuance of a wallet-relying party registration 
certificate, that Member State shall [...] (g) ensure that wallet-relying parties 
provide a URL to the privacy policy regarding the intended use.

requirements.requirement: Support mandated credential formats (ISO 18013-5 and W3C VC)
requirements.explanation:
Wallet solutions must support person identification data in both ISO/IEC 18013-5:2021 
(mDL/mDoc) format and W3C Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1. Relying parties 
accepting PID must be able to process at least one of these formats.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support the usage of person 
identification data and electronic attestations of attributes issued in compliance 
with the list of standards set out in Annex II.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Implement presentation protocols (ISO 18013-5, ISO 18013-7)
requirements.explanation:
For remote and proximity presentation of credentials, relying parties must implement 
the standardized protocols specified in the Annex to Regulation 2024/2982.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support protocols and interfaces 
for the presentation of attributes to wallet-relying parties, remotely, and where 
appropriate in proximity, in accordance with the standards set out in the Annex.

requirements.requirement: Support selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
The technical implementation must support selective disclosure, allowing users to 
share only specific attributes (e.g., "over 18") rather than full credentials.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support the selective disclosure 
of attributes of personal identification data and of electronic attestations of 
attributes.

requirements.requirement: Comply with WebAuthn specification for pseudonym generation
requirements.explanation:
When accepting pseudonymous authentication from wallet units, relying parties must 
support the WebAuthn specification as mandated in Annex V of the Integrity regulation.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation of pseudonyms for wallet users in compliance 
with the technical specifications set out in Annex V.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Support relying-party-specific pseudonyms
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may request a pseudonym that is unique and specific to them. This 
enables unlinkable authentication across different relying parties while allowing 
the same RP to recognize returning users.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation, upon the request of a wallet-relying party, 
of a pseudonym which is specific and unique to that wallet-relying party and provide 
this pseudonym to the wallet-relying party, either standalone or in combination with 
any person identification data or electronic attribute attestation requested by that 
wallet-relying party.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Verify proof of possession of private keys
requirements.explanation:
When receiving credentials, relying parties must verify that the wallet possesses 
the private key corresponding to the public key used in the cryptographic binding.
This prevents replay attacks and credential theft.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units support proving the possession of 
private keys corresponding to public keys used in cryptographic bindings.

requirements.requirement: Use valid Wallet-Relying Party Access Certificate
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must use a valid wallet-relying party access certificate when 
interacting with wallet units. This certificate authenticates the RP to the wallet.
requirements.legalText:
Regarding the protocols and interfaces referred to in Articles 4 and 5, wallet 
providers shall ensure that wallet units authenticate and validate the wallet-relying 
party access certificates where interacting with wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Support data erasure request protocol
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must implement the protocol allowing wallet users to request erasure 
of personal data that was shared through the wallet, supporting GDPR Article 17 rights.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units support protocols and interfaces 
allowing wallet users to request from wallet-relying parties, with whom they have 
interacted through those wallet units, the erasure of their personal data provided 
through those wallet units, in accordance with Article 17 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept EUDI Wallet for online services requiring e-ID
requirements.explanation:
When a public sector body requires electronic identification to access an online 
service, they must also accept EUDI Wallets provided in accordance with the regulation.
requirements.legalText:
Where Member States require electronic identification and authentication to access 
an online service provided by a public sector body, they shall also accept European 
Digital Identity Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Private sector: Accept EUDI Wallet where strong authentication is mandated
requirements.explanation:
Private relying parties (except micro/small enterprises) must accept EUDI Wallets 
when strong user authentication is required by law or contract in specified sectors.
requirements.legalText:
Where private relying parties that provide services, with the exception of 
microenterprises and small enterprises [...], are required by Union or national law 
to use strong user authentication for online identification or where strong user 
authentication for online identification is required by contractual obligation, 
including in the areas of transport, energy, banking, financial services, social 
security, health, drinking water, postal services, digital infrastructure, education 
or telecommunications, those private relying parties shall [...] also accept European 
Digital Identity Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Very large online platforms: Accept EUDI Wallet for user authentication
requirements.explanation:
Providers of very large online platforms (as defined in DSA Article 33) must accept 
EUDI Wallets for user authentication upon voluntary user request.
requirements.legalText:
Where providers of very large online platforms as referred to in Article 33 of 
Regulation (EU) 2022/2065 [...] require user authentication for access to online 
services, they shall also accept and facilitate the use of European Digital Identity 
Wallets that are provided in accordance with this Regulation for user authentication 
only upon the voluntary request of the user and in respect of the minimum data 
necessary for the specific online service for which authentication is requested.

requirements.requirement: Support wallet-based Strong Customer Authentication (SCA)
requirements.explanation:
Payment service providers must accept the EUDI Wallet as a means of performing 
Strong Customer Authentication for payment transactions and account access.
requirements.legalText:
Where private relying parties that provide services [...] are required by Union or 
national law to use strong user authentication for online identification [...] 
including in the areas of [...] banking, financial services [...] those private 
relying parties shall [...] also accept European Digital Identity Wallets.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic signatures regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect or admissibility of an electronic signature 
solely because it is in electronic form or doesn't meet qualified signature requirements.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic signature shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that it 
does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic signatures.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic signatures as equivalent to handwritten
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic signatures have the equivalent legal effect of a handwritten 
signature and must be treated as such by relying parties.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic signature shall have the equivalent legal effect of a 
handwritten signature.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified signatures from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic signature issued in 
any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic signature based on a qualified certificate issued in one 
Member State shall be recognised as a qualified electronic signature in all other 
Member States.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept advanced signatures in defined formats
requirements.explanation:
Public sector relying parties requiring advanced electronic signatures must accept 
them in the formats defined by Commission implementing acts, ensuring interoperability.
requirements.legalText:
If a Member State requires an advanced electronic signature to use an online service 
offered by, or on behalf of, a public sector body, that Member State shall recognise 
advanced electronic signatures, advanced electronic signatures based on a qualified 
certificate for electronic signatures, and qualified electronic signatures in at least 
the formats or using methods defined in the implementing acts referred to in paragraph 5.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Not require higher than qualified signature for cross-border
requirements.explanation:
For cross-border services, public sector bodies cannot require a security level 
higher than qualified electronic signature, ensuring accessibility across Member States.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall not request for cross-border use in an online service offered by 
a public sector body an electronic signature at a higher security level than the 
qualified electronic signature.

requirements.requirement: Validate qualified electronic signatures correctly
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties should use a validation process that confirms the qualified signature's 
validity, including checking certificates, revocation status, time of signing, and 
data integrity.
requirements.legalText:
The process for the validation of a qualified electronic signature shall confirm 
the validity of a qualified electronic signature provided that: (a) the certificate 
that supports the signature was, at the time of signing, a qualified certificate 
[...]; (b) the qualified certificate was issued by a qualified trust service provider 
and was valid at the time of signing; (c) the signature validation data corresponds 
to the data provided to the relying party; (d) the unique set of data representing 
the signatory in the certificate is correctly provided to the relying party; 
(e) the use of any pseudonym is clearly indicated to the relying party [...].

requirements.requirement: Validate advanced signatures based on qualified certificates
requirements.explanation:
When receiving advanced electronic signatures based on qualified certificates, relying 
parties should ensure proper validation according to the defined process.
requirements.legalText:
The process for the validation of an advanced electronic signature based on a 
qualified certificate shall confirm the validity of an advanced electronic signature 
based on a qualified certificate, provided that: (a) the certificate that supports 
the signature was, at the time of signing, a qualified certificate [...]; 
(c) the signature validation data corresponds to the data provided to the relying party; 
(d) the unique set of data representing the signatory in the certificate is correctly 
provided to the relying party; (e) the use of any pseudonym is clearly indicated to 
the relying party [...].

requirements.requirement: Ensure validation system allows detection of security issues
requirements.explanation:
When using a validation system for qualified electronic signatures, relying parties 
must ensure the system provides the correct validation result AND enables them to 
detect any security-relevant issues that may affect the signature's validity.
requirements.legalText:
The system used for validating the qualified electronic signature shall provide to 
the relying party the correct result of the validation process and shall allow the 
relying party to detect any security relevant issues.

requirements.requirement: Consider using qualified validation services
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may use qualified validation services to validate qualified electronic 
signatures, receiving automated, reliable validation results.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified validation service for qualified electronic signatures may only be 
provided by a qualified trust service provider who: (a) provides validation in 
compliance with Article 32(1); and (b) allows relying parties to receive the result 
of the validation process in an automated manner, which is reliable, efficient and 
bears the advanced electronic signature or advanced electronic seal of the provider 
of the qualified validation service.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic seals regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect or admissibility of an electronic seal 
solely because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic seal shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that 
it does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic seals.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic seals' presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic seals enjoy the presumption of data integrity and origin correctness.
RPs should rely on these presumptions when verifying sealed data.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic seal shall enjoy the presumption of integrity of the data and 
of correctness of the origin of that data to which the qualified electronic seal is linked.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic seals from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic seal issued in 
any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic seal based on a qualified certificate issued in one Member State 
shall be recognised as a qualified electronic seal in all other Member States.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Accept advanced seals in defined formats
requirements.explanation:
Public sector relying parties requiring advanced electronic seals must accept 
them in the formats defined by Commission implementing acts.
requirements.legalText:
If a Member State requires an advanced electronic seal in order to use an online service 
offered by, or on behalf of, a public sector body, that Member State shall recognise 
advanced electronic seals, advanced electronic seals based on a qualified certificate 
for electronic seals and qualified electronic seals at least in the formats or using 
methods defined in the implementing acts referred to in paragraph 5.

requirements.requirement: Validate qualified electronic seals correctly
requirements.explanation:
Articles 32-34 for signature validation apply mutatis mutandis to electronic seals.
RPs should validate seals using the same processes as signatures.
requirements.legalText:
Articles 32, 33 and 34 shall apply mutatis mutandis to the validation and 
preservation of qualified electronic seals.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic time stamps regardless of electronic form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of an electronic time stamp solely 
because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic time stamp shall not be denied legal effect and admissibility as 
evidence in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic 
form or that it does not meet the requirements of the qualified electronic time stamp.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified time stamps' presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic time stamps enjoy the presumption of accuracy of date/time 
and integrity of the bound data. RPs should rely on these presumptions.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic time stamp shall enjoy the presumption of the accuracy of 
the date and the time it indicates and the integrity of the data to which the 
date and time are bound.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified time stamps from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. A qualified electronic time stamp issued 
in any EU Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic time stamp issued in one Member State shall be recognised 
as a qualified electronic time stamp in all Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic registered delivery data regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of data sent/received using electronic 
registered delivery services solely because it is electronic.
requirements.legalText:
Data sent and received using an electronic registered delivery service shall not 
be denied legal effect and admissibility as evidence in legal proceedings solely 
on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or that it does not meet the 
requirements of the qualified electronic registered delivery service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified registered delivery presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Qualified electronic registered delivery services enjoy presumptions of data integrity,
sender/addressee identification, and date/time accuracy.
requirements.legalText:
Data sent and received using a qualified electronic registered delivery service 
shall enjoy the presumption of the integrity of the data, the sending of that data 
by the identified sender, its receipt by the identified addressee and the accuracy 
of the date and time of sending and receipt indicated by the qualified electronic 
registered delivery service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified certificates for website authentication
requirements.explanation:
Qualified certificates for website authentication issued in any Member State 
must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified certificate for website authentication issued in one Member State 
shall be recognised as a qualified certificate for website authentication in 
all other Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic attestations of attributes regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of an electronic attestation of attributes 
solely because it is in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic attestation of attributes shall not be denied legal effect or 
admissibility as evidence in legal proceedings on the sole ground that it is 
in electronic form or that it does not meet the requirements for qualified 
electronic attestations of attributes.

requirements.requirement: Recognize legal effect of qualified EAA and public sector EAA
requirements.explanation:
Qualified EAA and attestations issued by public sector bodies responsible for 
authentic sources have the same legal effect as paper attestations.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic attestation of attributes and attestations of attributes 
issued by, or on behalf of, a public sector body responsible for an authentic 
source shall have the same legal effect as lawfully issued attestations in paper form.

requirements.requirement: Recognize public sector EAA from all Member States
requirements.explanation:
Cross-border recognition is mandatory. EAA issued by a public sector body in 
one Member State must be recognized in all other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
An attestation of attributes issued by or on behalf of a public sector body 
responsible for an authentic source in one Member State shall be recognised 
as an attestation of attributes issued by or on behalf of a public sector body 
responsible for an authentic source in all Member States.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronically archived data regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of electronically preserved data solely 
because it is electronic or not preserved using a qualified archiving service.
requirements.legalText:
Electronic data and electronic documents preserved using an electronic archiving 
service shall not be denied legal effect or admissibility as evidence in legal 
proceedings on the sole ground that they are in electronic form or that they are 
not preserved using a qualified electronic archiving service.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified archiving service presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Data preserved using qualified electronic archiving enjoys the presumption of 
integrity and origin for the duration of preservation.
requirements.legalText:
Electronic data and electronic documents preserved using a qualified electronic 
archiving service shall enjoy the presumption of their integrity and of their 
origin for the duration of the preservation period by the qualified trust service provider.

requirements.requirement: Accept electronic ledger records regardless of form
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties cannot deny legal effect of electronic ledger records solely 
because they are in electronic form.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic ledger shall not be denied legal effect or admissibility as evidence 
in legal proceedings solely on the grounds that it is in an electronic form or 
that it does not meet the requirements for qualified electronic ledgers.

requirements.requirement: Recognize qualified electronic ledger presumptions
requirements.explanation:
Data records in a qualified electronic ledger enjoy the presumption of unique, 
accurate sequential chronological ordering and integrity.
requirements.legalText:
Data records contained in a qualified electronic ledger shall enjoy the presumption 
of their unique and accurate sequential chronological ordering and of their integrity.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Recognize e-ID from other Member States
requirements.explanation:
When requiring electronic identification for online services, public sector RPs 
must accept notified e-ID means from other Member States at substantial/high levels.
requirements.legalText:
When an electronic identification using an electronic identification means and 
authentication is required under national law or by administrative practice to 
access a service provided by a public sector body online in one Member State, 
the electronic identification means issued in another Member State shall be 
recognised in the first Member State for the purposes of cross-border authentication 
for that service online.

requirements.requirement: Public sector: Ensure unequivocal identity matching for cross-border
requirements.explanation:
When acting as relying parties for cross-border services, public sector bodies 
must ensure unequivocal identity matching for users with notified e-ID or EUDI Wallets.
requirements.legalText:
When acting as relying parties for cross-border services, Member States shall 
ensure unequivocal identity matching for natural persons using notified electronic 
identification means or European Digital Identity Wallets.

requirements.requirement: Protect personal data used for identity matching
requirements.explanation:
For cross-border identity matching, appropriate technical and organisational measures 
must be in place to protect personal data and prevent user profiling.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall provide for technical and organisational measures to ensure 
a high level of protection of personal data used for identity matching and to 
prevent the profiling of users.

requirements.requirement: Access certificate revocation status information
requirements.explanation:
Qualified trust service providers must provide RPs with certificate validity/revocation 
information. RPs should use this to verify certificate status before relying on them.
requirements.legalText:
With regard to paragraph 3, qualified trust service providers issuing qualified 
certificates shall provide to any relying party information on the validity or 
revocation status of qualified certificates issued by them. This information 
shall be made available at least on a per certificate basis at any time and 
beyond the validity period of the certificate in an automated manner that is 
reliable, free of charge and efficient.

requirements.requirement: Request only necessary and proportionate attributes
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties shall only request attributes that are necessary and proportionate 
for the specific service. Over-requesting data violates data minimization principles.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall not request users to provide any data other than that indicated 
pursuant to paragraph 2, point (c).

requirements.requirement: Support selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
Systems must be capable of processing selectively disclosed attributes. Users 
should not be forced to reveal more data than necessary (e.g., verifying "over 18" 
without revealing exact birth date).
requirements.legalText:
European Digital Identity Wallets shall enable the user, in a manner that is 
user-friendly, transparent, and traceable by the user, to: (a) securely request, 
obtain, select, combine, store, delete, share and present, under the sole control 
of the user, person identification data and, where applicable, in combination with 
electronic attestations of attributes, to authenticate to relying parties online 
and, where appropriate, in offline mode, in order to access public and private 
services, while ensuring that selective disclosure of data is possible.

requirements.requirement: Do not track wallet usage across services (unlinkability)
requirements.explanation:
The technical framework must prevent tracking or correlation of wallet usage 
across different services, unless the user explicitly consents.
requirements.legalText:
The technical framework of the European Digital Identity Wallet shall: (a) not allow 
providers of electronic attestations of attributes or any other party, after the 
issuance of the attestation of attributes, to obtain data that allows transactions 
or user behaviour to be tracked, linked or correlated, or knowledge of transactions 
or user behaviour to be otherwise obtained, unless explicitly authorised by the user.

requirements.requirement: Enable privacy preserving unlinkability for non-identified attestations
requirements.explanation:
When attestations don't require user identification, privacy-preserving techniques 
must ensure unlinkability across different relying parties.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units [...] enable privacy preserving 
techniques which ensure unlinkability where the electronic attestations of 
attributes do not require the identification of the wallet user, when presenting 
attestations or person identification data across different wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Allow pseudonyms where legal identity is not required
requirements.explanation:
Users cannot be prohibited from using pseudonyms when there is no legal requirement 
for identity verification.
requirements.legalText:
Without prejudice to specific rules of Union or national law requiring users to 
identify themselves or to the legal effect given to pseudonyms under national law, 
the use of pseudonyms that are chosen by the user shall not be prohibited.

requirements.requirement: Process data in accordance with GDPR
requirements.explanation:
All personal data received from wallets must be processed in full compliance 
with GDPR, including lawful basis, storage limitation, and data subject rights.
requirements.legalText:
This Regulation is without prejudice to Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European 
Parliament and of the Council.

requirements.requirement: Maintain alternative means of identification
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may maintain alternative authentication methods. EUDI Wallet 
acceptance requirements do not prevent offering other identification means.
requirements.legalText:
The use of European Digital Identity Wallets shall be voluntary. Access to public 
and private services, access to the labour market and freedom to conduct business 
shall not in any way be restricted or made disadvantageous to natural or legal 
persons that do not use European Digital Identity Wallets. It shall remain possible 
to access public and private services by other existing identification and 
authentication means.

requirements.requirement: Support reporting to data protection authorities
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must be prepared to be reported to data protection authorities 
through the wallet's reporting mechanism if users suspect unlawful data requests.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units allow wallet users to easily report 
wallet-relying parties to supervisory authorities established under Article 51 of 
Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

requirements.requirement: Perform data protection impact assessments for wallet data processing
requirements.explanation:
Recital 17 emphasizes that relying parties should comply with GDPR safeguards, 
particularly by performing data protection impact assessments and consulting 
data protection authorities prior to processing where there is high risk.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties should comply with the safeguards offered by Articles 35 and 36 
of [Regulation (EU) 2016/679], in particular by performing data protection impact 
assessments and by consulting the competent data protection authorities prior to 
data processing where data protection impact assessments indicate that the 
processing would result in a high risk.

requirements.requirement: Apply data minimization - request only necessary data
requirements.explanation:
Recital 56 emphasizes that any request for information should be necessary, 
proportionate to the intended use, and in line with data minimisation principles.
requirements.legalText:
Any request by the relying party for information from the user of a European 
Digital Identity Wallet should be necessary for, and proportionate to, the 
intended use in a given case, should be in line with the principle of data 
minimisation and should ensure transparency as regards which data is shared 
and for what purposes.

requirements.requirement: Accept pseudonymous access where identification not legally required
requirements.explanation:
Recital 60 clarifies that unless specific rules require user identification, 
accessing services by using a pseudonym should not be prohibited.
requirements.legalText:
Unless specific rules of Union or national law require users to identify 
themselves, accessing services by using a pseudonym should not be prohibited.

requirements.requirement: Enable selective disclosure of attributes
requirements.explanation:
Recital 59 emphasizes that selective disclosure is a core design feature of 
wallets, allowing users to share only necessary parts of their data.
requirements.legalText:
Selective disclosure is a concept empowering the owner of data to disclose 
only certain parts of a larger data set, in order for the receiving entity 
to obtain only such information as is necessary for the provision of a 
service requested by a user. The European Digital Identity Wallet should 
technically enable the selective disclosure of attributes to relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Very large online platforms must accept wallet authentication
requirements.explanation:
Recital 57 states that very large online platforms (as defined in DSA) that 
require authentication should accept EUDI Wallets upon user request, while 
respecting data minimisation and pseudonym rights.
requirements.legalText:
Where very large online platforms...require users to be authenticated in order 
to access online services, those platforms should be required to accept the use 
of European Digital Identity Wallets upon the voluntary request of the user. 
Users should be under no obligation to use a European Digital Identity Wallet 
to access private services... However, if users wish to do so, very large online 
platforms should accept them for that purpose, while respecting the principle 
of data minimisation and the right of the users to use freely chosen pseudonyms.

requirements.requirement: Support ISO/IEC 18013-5 data format for PID
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must be able to process Person Identification Data presented 
in the ISO/IEC 18013-5:2021 format (mDoc). This is one of two mandatory formats 
for PID.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Support W3C Verifiable Credentials data format for PID
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must be able to process Person Identification Data presented 
in the W3C Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1 format. This is one of two 
mandatory formats for PID.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Process mandatory PID attributes correctly
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must correctly process the mandatory PID attributes: 
family_name, given_name, birth_date, birth_place, and nationality. 
These are always present in valid PID credentials.
requirements.legalText:
Mandatory attributes: family_name (current last name(s)), given_name 
(current first name(s)), birth_date (day, month, year), birth_place 
(country/state/city of birth), nationality (alpha-2 country codes).

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Handle optional PID attributes when present
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties should correctly process optional PID attributes when 
presented, including: resident_address, personal_administrative_number, 
portrait, family_name_birth, given_name_birth, sex, email_address, 
and mobile_phone_number.
requirements.legalText:
Optional attributes include: resident_address, resident_country, 
resident_state, resident_city, resident_postal_code, resident_street, 
resident_house_number, personal_administrative_number, portrait, 
family_name_birth, given_name_birth, sex, email_address, mobile_phone_number.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Verify PID validity status before relying
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must check the validity status of presented PID before 
relying on it. The location of validity status information is included 
in the PID metadata (location_status attribute).
requirements.legalText:
Where providers of person identification data revoke person identification 
data issued to wallet units, they shall make publicly available the validity 
status of person identification data they issue, in a privacy preserving 
manner, and indicate the location of that information in the person 
identification data.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Process legal person PID attributes
requirements.explanation:
When processing legal person identification data, relying parties must 
handle the mandatory attributes (current legal name, unique identifier) 
and optional attributes (address, VAT, tax reference, LEI, EORI, etc.).
requirements.legalText:
Legal person mandatory data: current legal name; unique identifier 
constructed by the sending Member State. Optional: current address, 
VAT registration number, tax reference number, European unique identifier, 
Legal Entity Identifier (LEI), EORI, excise number.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977
legalSourceInfo.description: Rules for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes

requirements.requirement: Verify wallet unit attestation validity before transactions
requirements.explanation:
Before accepting credentials from a wallet, relying parties should verify the 
validity status of the wallet unit attestation. This ensures the wallet unit 
is still valid and not revoked.
requirements.legalText:
Where wallet providers have revoked wallet unit attestations, they shall make 
publicly available the validity status of the wallet unit attestation in a 
privacy preserving manner and describe the location of that information in 
the wallet unit attestation.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Comply with embedded disclosure policies in attestations
requirements.explanation:
Electronic attestations of attributes may contain embedded disclosure policies 
that specify conditions the relying party must meet to access the attestation. 
The wallet verifies RP compliance and informs the user.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet instances shall verify whether the wallet-relying party complies with 
the requirements of the embedded disclosure policy and inform the wallet user 
of the result.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Request RP-specific pseudonyms when appropriate
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties may request pseudonyms that are specific and unique to them, 
allowing persistent pseudonymous authentication without requiring full identity 
disclosure. The pseudonym can be requested standalone or with other data.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation, upon the request of a wallet-relying 
party, of a pseudonym which is specific and unique to that wallet-relying party 
and provide this pseudonym to the wallet-relying party, either standalone or in 
combination with any person identification data or electronic attribute 
attestation requested by that wallet-relying party.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Support mandatory data formats from Annex II
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must support the data formats specified in Annex II of 2024/2979 
for person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes. This 
includes ISO/IEC 18013-5 and W3C Verifiable Credentials.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support the usage of 
person identification data and electronic attestations of attributes issued 
in compliance with the list of standards set out in Annex II.

Annex II: ISO/IEC.18013-5:2021; 'Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1', 
W3C Recommendation, 3 March 2022.

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Support signature formats from Annex IV when requesting signatures
requirements.explanation:
When relying parties request electronic signatures or seals from wallet users, 
they must support the mandatory signature formats specified in Annex IV, and 
may optionally support XAdES, JAdES, CAdES, and ASiC formats.
requirements.legalText:
Signature creation applications shall have the following functions:
(c) creating signatures or seals in accordance with at least the mandatory 
formats referred to in Annex IV.

Annex IV optional formats: XAdES (XML), JAdES (JSON), CAdES (CMS), ASiC (containers).

legalSourceInfo.title: Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2979
legalSourceInfo.description: Wallet integrity, core functionalities, and trust infrastructure

requirements.requirement: Receive and act on wallet security breach notifications
requirements.explanation:
Registered relying parties will receive notifications within 24 hours when 
wallet solutions they depend on experience security breaches leading to 
suspension. RPs should have processes to handle such notifications.
requirements.legalText:
Information in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible manner about the 
suspension of the provision and the use of a wallet solution shall be provided, 
without undue delay and no later than 24 hours after the suspension of the 
provision and the use of the wallet solution, to:
(d) the wallet-relying parties registered in accordance with Article 5b of 
Regulation (EU) No 910/2014.

requirements.requirement: Receive wallet re-establishment notifications
requirements.explanation:
When a previously suspended wallet solution is re-established after remediation, 
relying parties will receive notifications. RPs should update their systems 
to resume accepting credentials from the re-established wallet.
requirements.legalText:
Where a Member State re-establishes a wallet solution, that Member State shall 
ensure that information about that fact is provided without undue delay to all 
parties having received information on the suspension of the provision and the 
use of that wallet solution in accordance with Article 5(1).

requirements.requirement: Receive wallet withdrawal notifications
requirements.explanation:
When wallet solutions are withdrawn (either due to severity or failure to 
remedy within 3 months), registered RPs receive notifications within 24 hours. 
RPs must stop accepting credentials from withdrawn wallet solutions.
requirements.legalText:
Information in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible manner about the 
withdrawal of a wallet solution shall be provided, without undue delay and no 
later than 24 hours after the withdrawal of the wallet solution, to:
(d) the wallet-relying parties registered in accordance with Article 5b of 
Regulation (EU) No 910/2014.

requirements.requirement: Perform unequivocal identity matching for cross-border users
requirements.explanation:
Public sector relying parties offering cross-border services must implement 
identity matching processes to link wallet credentials or notified eID means 
to existing user records or registers.
requirements.legalText:
Where a public sector body acts as a relying party in the context of an online 
cross-border service offered by or on behalf of that public sector body, Member 
States shall ensure that the process set out in paragraph 2 is used to ensure 
unequivocal identity matching of natural persons.

requirements.requirement: Use mandatory PID attributes for wallet-based identity matching
requirements.explanation:
When users authenticate via EUDI Wallet, relying parties must use the mandatory 
PID attributes from 2024/2977 Annex Section 1 for identity matching, plus any 
optional data needed to ensure uniqueness.
requirements.legalText:
When reliance is on a wallet, the information to be used for unequivocal identity 
matching shall be the mandatory person identification data set out in Section 1 
of the Annex to Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2977, together with any optional 
data that is needed to ensure that the presented dataset is unique.

requirements.requirement: Handle orthographic variations in identity matching
requirements.explanation:
Identity matching must not be affected by differences in transliteration, blank 
spaces, hyphenation, concatenation, and similar orthographic variations required 
under Union or national law.
requirements.legalText:
The outcome of the process described in paragraph 5 shall, to the extent possible, 
not be affected by differences in transliteration, blank spaces, hyphenation, 
concatenation, and similar orthographic variations that are required under Union 
law or national law of the Member State.

requirements.requirement: Inform users of successful identity matching outcomes
requirements.explanation:
When identity matching is successful, relying parties must inform users that 
they have been granted access, whether they were matched to an existing record 
or registered as a new user, and options for reusing the match.
requirements.legalText:
The first time a user performs the identity matching process and it is deemed 
successful, the relying party or the party acting on its behalf shall ensure 
that the user is informed of the fact that the user has been granted access 
to the service to which they requested access.

requirements.requirement: Inform users when identity matching fails and provide alternatives
requirements.explanation:
When identity matching is unsuccessful, relying parties must inform users why 
the match failed and provide information about alternative methods or 
complementary processes available.
requirements.legalText:
Where an identity matching process is deemed unsuccessful, the relying party 
or the party acting on its behalf shall ensure that the user of a notified 
electronic identification means or of a wallet is informed if:
(a) the data made available was not successfully and unequivocally matched;
(b) other options for identity matching or other methods for gaining access 
to the service are available.

requirements.requirement: Retain identity matching logs for 6-12 months
requirements.explanation:
Relying parties must keep logs of identity matching processes including values 
used, timestamps, documentation, and outcomes. Retention must be 6-12 months 
minimum, or longer if required by law.

requirements.requirement: Member States shall designate one or more supervisory bodies for EUDIW
requirements.explanation:
Member States must designate one or more supervisory bodies established in
their territory for the EUDIW framework. These bodies must be given necessary
powers and adequate resources for effective, efficient and independent operation.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall designate one or more supervisory bodies established in
their territory. The supervisory bodies designated pursuant to the first
subparagraph shall be given the necessary powers and adequate resources for
the exercise of their tasks in an effective, efficient and independent manner.

requirements.requirement: Member States shall designate a supervisory body for trust services
requirements.explanation:
Member States must designate a supervisory body for trust service supervision,
either in their own territory or upon mutual agreement, in another Member State.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall designate a supervisory body established in their territory
or designate, upon mutual agreement with another Member State, a supervisory
body established in that other Member State. That supervisory body shall be
responsible for supervisory tasks in the designating Member State as regards
trust services. The supervisory bodies designated pursuant to the first
subparagraph shall be given the necessary powers and adequate resources for
the exercise of their tasks.

requirements.requirement: Notify Commission of designated supervisory bodies
requirements.explanation:
Member States must notify the Commission of their designated supervisory
bodies' names and addresses, and any subsequent changes.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall notify to the Commission the names and the addresses of
their supervisory bodies designated pursuant to paragraph 1 and any subsequent
changes thereto. The Commission shall publish a list of the notified
supervisory bodies.

requirements.requirement: Supervise EUDIW providers through ex ante and ex post activities
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must supervise EUDIW providers to ensure they and their
wallets meet all regulatory requirements through both preventive (ex ante)
and reactive (ex post) supervisory activities.
requirements.legalText:
The role of the supervisory bodies shall be: (a) to supervise providers of
European Digital Identity Wallets established in the designating Member State
and to ensure, by means of ex ante and ex post supervisory activities, that
those providers and European Digital Identity Wallets they provide meet the
requirements laid down in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Take action on EUDIW provider infringements
requirements.explanation:
When informed that EUDIW providers or their wallets infringe the regulation,
supervisory bodies must take necessary action through ex post supervision.
requirements.legalText:
To take action, if necessary, in relation to providers of European Digital
Identity Wallets established in the territory of the designating Member State,
by means of ex post supervisory activities, when informed that providers or
European Digital Identity Wallets that they provide infringe this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Cooperate with other supervisory bodies per Articles 46c and 46e
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must cooperate with their counterparts in other Member
States and provide assistance in accordance with the single point of contact
and Cooperation Group mechanisms.
requirements.legalText:
The tasks of the supervisory bodies shall include, in particular, the following:
(a) to cooperate with other supervisory bodies and to provide them with
assistance in accordance with Articles 46c and 46e.

requirements.requirement: Request information to monitor EUDIW compliance
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies have the power to request any information necessary
to monitor compliance with the regulation from EUDIW providers.
requirements.legalText: To request information necessary to monitor compliance with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Inform NIS2 authorities of significant security breaches
requirements.explanation:
When aware of significant security breaches or loss of integrity, supervisory
bodies must inform the relevant NIS2 competent authorities and single points
of contact, and may require public disclosure.
requirements.legalText:
To inform the relevant competent authorities designated or established pursuant
to Article 8(1) of Directive (EU) 2022/2555 of the Member States concerned of
any significant security breaches or loss of integrity of which they become
aware in the performance of their tasks and, in the case of a significant
security breach or loss of integrity which concerns other Member States, to
inform the single point of contact designated or established pursuant to
Article 8(3) of Directive (EU) 2022/2555 of the Member State concerned and
the single points of contact designated pursuant to Article 46c(1) of this
Regulation in the other Member States concerned, and to inform the public or
require providers of European Digital Identity Wallet to do so where the
supervisory body determines that disclosure of the security breach or of the
loss of integrity would be in the public interest.

requirements.requirement: Carry out on-site inspections and off-site supervision
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies have the power to conduct both on-site inspections
and off-site supervision of EUDIW providers.
requirements.legalText: To carry out on-site inspections and off-site supervision.

requirements.requirement: Require EUDIW providers to remedy non-compliance
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies can require EUDIW providers to remedy any failure
to fulfil regulatory requirements.
requirements.legalText:
To require that providers of European Digital Identity Wallets remedy any
failure to fulfil the requirements laid down in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Suspend or cancel relying party registrations for fraud
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies can suspend or cancel the relying party registration
in cases of illegal or fraudulent use of the EUDIW.
requirements.legalText:
To suspend or cancel the registration and inclusion of relying parties in
the mechanism referred to in Article 5b(7) in the case of illegal or
fraudulent use of the European Digital Identity Wallet.

requirements.requirement: Cooperate with data protection authorities on breaches
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must cooperate with data protection authorities,
informing them of personal data protection infringements and breaches.
requirements.legalText:
To cooperate with competent supervisory authorities established pursuant
to Article 51 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679, in particular, by informing them
without undue delay, where personal data protection rules appear to have
been infringed and about security breaches which appear to constitute
personal data breaches.

requirements.requirement: Order suspension or cessation of non-compliant EUDIW provision
requirements.explanation:
If an EUDIW provider fails to remedy non-compliance, the supervisory body
may order suspension or cessation of wallet provision, notifying other
bodies, the Commission, relying parties and users.
requirements.legalText:
Where the supervisory body requires the provider of a European Digital
Identity Wallet to remedy any failure to fulfil requirements and that
provider does not act accordingly and, if applicable, within a time limit
set by that supervisory body, the supervisory body may, taking into account,
in particular, the extent, duration and consequences of that failure, order
the provider to suspend or to cease the provision of the European Digital
Identity Wallet. The supervisory body shall inform the supervisory bodies
of other Member States, the Commission, relying parties and users of the
European Digital Identity Wallet without undue delay of the decision to
require the suspension or cessation of the provision.

requirements.requirement: Submit annual activity report to Commission by 31 March
requirements.explanation:
Each supervisory body must submit an annual report on its main activities
to the Commission by 31 March each year.
requirements.legalText:
By 31 March each year, each supervisory body designated pursuant to
paragraph 1 shall submit to the Commission a report on its main activities
in the previous calendar year. The Commission shall make those annual
reports available to the European Parliament and the Council.

requirements.requirement: Supervise QTSPs through ex ante and ex post activities
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must supervise qualified trust service providers to
ensure they and their services meet all regulatory requirements through
both preventive and reactive supervision.
requirements.legalText:
The role of the supervisory bodies shall be: (a) to supervise qualified
trust service providers established in the territory of the designating
Member State and to ensure, by means of ex ante and ex post supervisory
activities, that those qualified trust service providers and the qualified
trust services that they provide meet the requirements laid down in this
Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Take action on non-qualified TSP non-compliance
requirements.explanation:
When informed that non-qualified TSPs allegedly do not meet requirements,
supervisory bodies must take necessary action through ex post supervision.
requirements.legalText:
To take action, if necessary, in relation to non-qualified trust service
providers established in the territory of the designating Member State, by
means of ex post supervisory activities, when informed that those non-qualified
trust service providers or the trust services they provide allegedly do not
meet the requirements laid down in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Inform NIS2 authorities of trust service security breaches
requirements.explanation:
When aware of significant security breaches or loss of integrity affecting
trust services, supervisory bodies must inform the relevant NIS2 authorities.
requirements.legalText:
To inform the relevant competent authorities designated or established
pursuant to Article 8(1) of Directive (EU) 2022/2555 of the Member States
concerned of any significant security breach or loss of integrity of which
it becomes aware in the performance of its tasks and, in the case of a
significant security breach or loss of integrity which concerns other Member
States, to inform the single point of contact...and to inform the public or
require the trust service provider to do so where the supervisory body
determines that disclosure of the breach of security or loss of integrity
would be in the public interest.

requirements.requirement: Cooperate with other supervisory bodies per Articles 46c and 46e
requirements.explanation:
Trust service supervisory bodies must cooperate with their counterparts
in other Member States through the single point of contact and Cooperation
Group mechanisms.
requirements.legalText:
To cooperate with other supervisory bodies and to provide them with
assistance in accordance with Articles 46c and 46e.

requirements.requirement: Analyse conformity assessment reports from CABs
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must analyse the conformity assessment reports
submitted by QTSPs per Articles 20(1) and 21(1).
requirements.legalText:
To analyse the conformity assessment reports referred to in Article 20(1)
and Article 21(1).

requirements.requirement: Submit annual activity report to Commission by 31 March
requirements.explanation:
Each trust service supervisory body must submit an annual report on
its main activities to the Commission by 31 March each year.
requirements.legalText:
To report to the Commission about its main activities in accordance with
paragraph 6 of this Article. By 31 March each year, each supervisory body
shall submit to the Commission a report on its main activities in the
previous calendar year.

requirements.requirement: Carry out audits or request CAB conformity assessments
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies can audit QTSPs directly or request a CAB to perform
a conformity assessment at the QTSP's expense.
requirements.legalText:
To carry out audits or request a conformity assessment body to perform a
conformity assessment of the qualified trust service providers in accordance
with Article 20(2).

requirements.requirement: Cooperate with data protection authorities on TSP breaches
requirements.explanation:
Trust service supervisory bodies must cooperate with data protection
authorities, informing them of personal data violations and security breaches.
requirements.legalText:
To cooperate with competent supervisory authorities established pursuant
to Article 51 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679, in particular, by informing them,
without undue delay, where personal data protection rules appear to have
been breached and about security breaches which appear to constitute personal
data breaches.

requirements.requirement: Grant qualified status to TSPs and services per Arts 20/21
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies have exclusive authority to grant qualified status
to trust service providers and their services.
requirements.legalText:
To grant qualified status to trust service providers and to the services
they provide, and to withdraw that status in accordance with Articles 20
and 21.

requirements.requirement: Inform trusted list body of qualified status decisions
requirements.explanation:
When granting or withdrawing qualified status, supervisory bodies must
inform the body responsible for the national trusted list.
requirements.legalText:
To inform the body responsible for the national trusted list referred to
in Article 22(3) of its decisions to grant or withdraw qualified status,
unless that body is also the supervisory body designated pursuant to
paragraph 1 of this Article.

requirements.requirement: Verify QTSP termination plans per Article 24(2)(h)
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must verify that QTSPs have proper termination plans
and that information remains accessible when they cease activities.
requirements.legalText:
To verify the existence and correct application of provisions on termination
plans where the qualified trust service provider ceases its activities,
including how information is kept accessible in accordance with Article 24(2),
point (h).

requirements.requirement: Require TSPs to remedy non-compliance with regulation
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies can require trust service providers to remedy any
failure to fulfil regulatory requirements.
requirements.legalText:
To require that trust service providers remedy any failure to fulfil the
requirements laid down in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Investigate web-browser claims on QWAC certificates
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies must investigate claims made by web browser providers
regarding qualified website authentication certificates.
requirements.legalText:
To investigate claims made by providers of web-browsers pursuant to
Article 45a and to take action if necessary.

requirements.requirement: May establish and maintain trust infrastructure per national law
requirements.explanation:
Member States may require their supervisory body to establish, maintain
and update a trust infrastructure in accordance with national law.
requirements.legalText:
Member States may require the supervisory body designated pursuant to
paragraph 1 to establish, maintain and update a trust infrastructure in
accordance with national law.

requirements.requirement: Member States shall designate a single point of contact
requirements.explanation:
Each Member State must designate a single point of contact for trust
services, EUDIW, and notified electronic identification schemes.
requirements.legalText:
Each Member State shall designate a single point of contact for trust
services, European Digital Identity Wallets and notified electronic
identification schemes.

requirements.requirement: SPOC exercises liaison function for cross-border cooperation
requirements.explanation:
The single point of contact facilitates cross-border cooperation between
supervisory bodies for TSPs and EUDIW providers, and with the Commission,
ENISA, and other competent authorities.
requirements.legalText:
Each single point of contact shall exercise a liaison function to facilitate
cross-border cooperation between the supervisory bodies for trust service
providers and between the supervisory bodies for the providers of European
Digital Identity Wallets and, where appropriate, with the Commission and
European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) and with other competent
authorities within its Member State.

requirements.requirement: Make SPOC contact details public and notify Commission
requirements.explanation:
Member States must make their single point of contact details public
and notify the Commission of any changes.
requirements.legalText:
Each Member State shall make public and, without undue delay, notify to
the Commission the names and the addresses of the single point of contact
designated pursuant to paragraph 1 and any subsequent change thereto.

requirements.requirement: May seek mutual assistance from other Member States' supervisory bodies
requirements.explanation:
Supervisory bodies may seek mutual assistance from their counterparts
in other Member States for supervision and enforcement of obligations.
requirements.legalText:
In order to facilitate the supervision and enforcement of obligations under
this Regulation, the supervisory bodies designated pursuant to Article 46a(1)
and Article 46b(1) may seek, including through the Cooperation Group
established pursuant to Article 46e(1), mutual assistance from the supervisory
bodies of another Member State where the provider of the European Digital
Identity Wallet or the trust service provider is established, or where its
network and information systems are located or its services are provided.

requirements.requirement: Inform and consult supervisory body in other Member State
requirements.explanation:
When applying supervisory and enforcement measures, bodies must inform
and consult the supervisory body from the other Member State concerned.
requirements.legalText:
The mutual assistance shall at least entail that: (a) the supervisory body
applying supervisory and enforcement measures in one Member State shall
inform and consult the supervisory body from the other Member State concerned.

requirements.requirement: May request another supervisory body to take supervisory measures
requirements.explanation:
A supervisory body may request another Member State's body to take
supervisory or enforcement measures, including conformity assessment
inspections.
requirements.legalText:
A supervisory body may request the supervisory body of another Member State
concerned to take supervisory or enforcement measures, including, for instance,
requests to carry out inspections related to the conformity assessment reports
as referred to in Articles 20 and 21 regarding the provision of trust services.

requirements.requirement: May carry out joint investigations with other Member States
requirements.explanation:
Where appropriate, supervisory bodies may conduct joint investigations
with their counterparts in other Member States.
requirements.legalText:
Where appropriate, supervisory bodies may carry out joint investigations
with the supervisory bodies of other Member States. The arrangements and
procedures for joint actions under the first subparagraph shall be agreed
upon and established by the Member States concerned in accordance with
their national law.

requirements.requirement: May refuse assistance on proportionality or competence grounds
requirements.explanation:
A supervisory body may refuse a request for assistance if it is
disproportionate, outside their competence, or incompatible with the regulation.
requirements.legalText:
A supervisory body to which a request for assistance is addressed may refuse
that request on any of the following grounds: (a) the assistance requested
is not proportionate to the supervisory activities carried out in accordance
with Articles 46a and 46b; (b) the supervisory body is not competent to
provide the requested assistance; (c) providing the requested assistance
would be incompatible with this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Participate in European Digital Identity Cooperation Group
requirements.explanation:
Member States must appoint representatives to the Cooperation Group
which supports cross-border cooperation on trust services, EUDIW, and
electronic identification schemes.
requirements.legalText:
The Cooperation Group shall be composed of representatives appointed by
the Member States and of the Commission. The Cooperation Group shall be
chaired by the Commission. The Commission shall provide the Cooperation
Group's Secretariat.

requirements.requirement: Exchange best practices on policy implementation
requirements.explanation:
Through the Cooperation Group, supervisory bodies exchange best practices
and information about implementing the regulation, assess sector developments,
and discuss cybersecurity aspects.
requirements.legalText:
The Cooperation Group shall have the following tasks: (c) in order to support
the supervisory bodies in the implementation of the provisions of this
Regulation: (i) exchange best practices and information regarding the
implementation of the provisions of this Regulation; (ii) assess the relevant
developments in the digital identity wallet, electronic identification and
trust services sectors; (iv) with the support of ENISA, exchange views,
best practices and information on relevant cybersecurity aspects concerning
European Digital Identity Wallets, electronic identification schemes and
trust services.

requirements.requirement: Organise joint meetings with NIS Cooperation Group
requirements.explanation:
The Cooperation Group organizes joint meetings with the NIS Cooperation
Group to exchange information on cyber threats, incidents, and standards.
requirements.legalText:
Organise joint meetings with the NIS Cooperation Group established pursuant
to Article 14(1) of Directive (EU) 2022/2555 to exchange relevant information
in relation to trust services and electronic identification related cyber
threats, incidents, vulnerabilities, awareness raising initiatives, trainings,
exercises and skills, capacity building, standards and technical specifications.

requirements.requirement: Participate in peer reviews of eID schemes to be notified
requirements.explanation:
Through the Cooperation Group, supervisory bodies participate in
peer reviews of electronic identification schemes before notification.
requirements.legalText:
The Cooperation Group shall have the following tasks: (d) organise peer
reviews of electronic identification schemes to be notified under this
Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Ensure effective and efficient cooperation in Cooperation Group
requirements.explanation:
Member States must ensure their designated representatives participate
effectively and efficiently in the Cooperation Group.
requirements.legalText:
Member States shall ensure effective and efficient cooperation of their
designated representatives in the Cooperation Group.

requirements.requirement: Provide annual breach summary to ENISA
requirements.explanation:
The supervisory body must provide ENISA once a year with a summary
of breach of security and loss of integrity notifications received
from trust service providers.
requirements.legalText:
The supervisory body shall provide ENISA once a year with a summary of
notifications of breach of security and loss of integrity received from
trust service providers.

requirements.requirement: Accept liability for damage caused by non-compliance
requirements.explanation:
Trust service providers are liable for damage caused intentionally or
negligently to any natural or legal person due to failure to comply
with the obligations under eIDAS.
requirements.legalText:
Trust service providers shall be liable for damage caused intentionally
or negligently to any natural or legal person due to a failure to comply
with the obligations under this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Limit liability through advance customer notification
requirements.explanation:
TSPs may limit their liability where they duly inform customers in
advance of usage limitations and those limitations are recognisable
to third parties.
requirements.legalText:
Where trust service providers duly inform their customers in advance of
the limitations on the use of the services they provide and where those
limitations are recognisable to third parties, trust service providers
shall not be liable for damages arising from the use of services
exceeding the indicated limitations.

requirements.requirement: Make services accessible to persons with disabilities
requirements.explanation:
Trust services and end-user products must be made available in plain
and intelligible language, in accordance with UNCRPD and Directive 2019/882.
requirements.legalText:
The provision of electronic identification means, trust services and
end-user products that are used in the provision of those services
shall be made available in plain and intelligible language, in accordance
with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with
Disabilities and with the accessibility requirements of Directive (EU) 2019/882.

requirements.requirement: Implement appropriate technical and organisational security measures
requirements.explanation:
TSPs must take measures to manage risks to the security of trust services,
ensuring security level is commensurate with risk, and take measures to
prevent and minimise impact of security incidents.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified and non-qualified trust service providers shall take appropriate
technical and organisational measures to manage the risks posed to the
security of the trust services they provide. Having regard to the latest
technological developments, those measures shall ensure that the level
of security is commensurate to the degree of risk. In particular, measures
shall be taken to prevent and minimise the impact of security incidents
and inform stakeholders of the adverse effects of any such incidents.

requirements.requirement: Notify security breaches within 24 hours
requirements.explanation:
TSPs must notify the supervisory body and relevant authorities of any
breach of security or loss of integrity within 24 hours of becoming aware.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified and non-qualified trust service providers shall, without undue
delay but in any event within 24 hours after having become aware of it,
notify the supervisory body and, where applicable, other relevant bodies,
such as the competent national body for information security or the data
protection authority, of any breach of security or loss of integrity that
has a significant impact on the trust service provided or on the personal
data maintained therein.

requirements.requirement: Notify affected persons of security breaches
requirements.explanation:
Where a breach is likely to adversely affect a person to whom the
trust service has been provided, the TSP must notify that person
without undue delay.
requirements.legalText:
Where the breach of security or loss of integrity is likely to adversely
affect a natural or legal person to whom the trusted service has been
provided, the trust service provider shall also notify the natural or
legal person of the breach of security or loss of integrity without
undue delay.

requirements.requirement: Implement risk management policies and measures
requirements.explanation:
Non-qualified TSPs must have appropriate policies and take measures
to manage risks, including registration/onboarding procedures, 
administrative checks, and service management.
requirements.legalText:
A non-qualified trust service provider providing non-qualified trust
services shall have appropriate policies and take corresponding measures
to manage legal, business, operational and other direct or indirect risks
to the provision of the non-qualified trust service, which shall include
at least measures relating to: (i) registration and onboarding procedures;
(ii) procedural or administrative checks; (iii) management and implementation.

requirements.requirement: Notify security breaches and disruptions within 24 hours
requirements.explanation:
Non-qualified TSPs must notify the supervisory body, affected individuals,
the public (if public interest), and other authorities of any significant
security breaches or service disruptions within 24 hours.
requirements.legalText:
Notifying the supervisory body, the identifiable affected individuals,
the public if it is of public interest and, where applicable, other
relevant competent authorities, of any security breaches or disruptions
in the provision of the service or the implementation of the measures...
that have a significant impact on the trust service provided or on the
personal data maintained therein, without undue delay and in any case
no later than 24 hours of having become aware.

requirements.requirement: Submit to conformity assessment audit every 24 months
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs must be audited at their own expense at least every 24 months
by a conformity assessment body, confirming compliance with eIDAS
and NIS2 Directive Article 21.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall be audited at their own expense
at least every 24 months by a conformity assessment body. The audit shall
confirm that the qualified trust service providers and the qualified trust
services provided by them fulfil the requirements laid down in this
Regulation and in Article 21 of Directive (EU) 2022/2555.

requirements.requirement: Submit conformity assessment report within 3 working days
requirements.explanation:
After each audit, QTSPs must submit the conformity assessment report
to the supervisory body within three working days of receipt.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall submit the resulting conformity
assessment report to the supervisory body within three working days of receipt.

requirements.requirement: Notify supervisory body one month before planned audits
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs must inform the supervisory body at least one month before any
planned audits and allow the body to participate as an observer.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall inform the supervisory body at
the latest one month before any planned audits and shall allow the
supervisory body to participate as an observer upon request.

requirements.requirement: Remedy non-compliance within set time limit
requirements.explanation:
Where a QTSP fails to meet requirements, they must remedy the failure
within the time limit set by the supervisory body, or face withdrawal
of qualified status.
requirements.legalText:
Where the qualified trust service provider fails to fulfil any of the
requirements set out by this Regulation, the supervisory body shall
require it to provide a remedy within a set time limit, if applicable.
Where that provider does not provide a remedy... the supervisory body
shall withdraw the qualified status.

requirements.requirement: Submit CAR to supervisory body before starting qualified services
requirements.explanation:
Before providing qualified trust services, a TSP must notify the
supervisory body with a conformity assessment report confirming
compliance with eIDAS and NIS2.
requirements.legalText:
Where trust service providers intend to start providing a qualified
trust service, they shall notify the supervisory body of their intention
